headline: Quick Almond Flour Pancakes
description: These almond flour pancakes are naturally gluten-free and a delicious and filling way to start your day. Serve with your favorite pancake toppings.

video.description: Almond flour is about to be your new favorite pancake ingredient!
video.name: Quick Almond Flour Pancakes

name: Quick Almond Flour Pancakes

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk together almond flour, water, eggs, maple syrup, and salt in a large bowl until smooth.
Heat oil on a griddle over medium heat.
Drop batter by large spoonfuls onto the griddle. Cook until bubbles form and edges are dry, 3 to 5 minutes. Flip and cook until bottoms are browned, 3 to 5 minutes. Repeat with remaining batter.

review.reviewBody: These were incredible, light and thin with so much flavor. I added cinnamon to the batter. SO good, would make again and again
These are delicious. When we make these, we make them silver dollar size. These also freeze very well.
I loved this recipe. Turned out exactly right. Will definitely make these again. My stove is old, so some patience required in waiting for pancakes to brown.

It was good but for some reason mine was falling apart. Like too crumbly. I substituted maple syrup with a little extra liquid and some brown sugar and added cinnamon. I think next time I'll add some vanilla to add some flavor. Also whicked the egg whites to make it fluffy instead of dense.
I was very good

I’ve tried fancy gluten free pancake mixes that were not as delicious as these. I used Walmart brand almond flour. Avocado oil and the maple syrup sweetener. Ate with side of sliced banana. Way better than those mixes! Browned up perfect, again I used Avocado oil for the cooking oil, flipped perfect and stayed together. Yummy.

I make this often. Half recipe since I’m only one eating it. One big pancake is sufficient and delicious. I omitted the salt just because I don’t like salt, didn’t feel the need for it. For me and my taste buds it’s just right.

So I made an account just to leave a review and this was my first experience with almond flour. I made this recipe twice. First time as directed but my syrup was the keto monk fruit syrup and you smell that syrup all day. Yes these are more dense but that was expected and they refrigerated well. Tasted fine though I had to limit myself due to being on a keto diet. Second time I replaced the syrup with two packets of stevia in the raw, and it made the batter thicker. They cooked just fine but may need to add more fluid of some sort to allow the batter to make a thinner pancake as I ended up with fewer that were very thick but cooked very well with the pan covered. Still tasted just fine but didn’t have that monk fruit taste Or smell I had the first time. I also ended up with fewer pancakes. So next time I will add more fluid and keep with the sugar substitute instead of syrup. This recipe works for me as a great base.
I really liked this! I suggest blueberries, because fruit seems like a really good compliment to these pancakes. I had just butter and syrup and...yum!
I love how very easy this was to mix and make. The pancakes were yummy and it's so nice to have an alternative for higher protein pancakes.
good taste, crumbly. needs binder.

Pancakes were flat and dry. I added some vanilla extract for flavor. Next time I would double the maple syrup and add baking powder and or baking soda. With a few minor alterations, this could be a very good low carb alternative for traditional pancakes.
Excellent, easy, quick, delicious and satisfying! We topped them with a blend of fresh blueberries and homemade plain yogurt ! Thanks for this amazing recipe!
terrible crumbly

I really like these pancakes, simple and taste really good. I did add a little vanilla extract and a pinch of cinnamon. I also doubled the recipe for more pancakes. Yummy! Thank you for sharing your recipe.
So good! I cooked these in coconut oil. Absolutely simple and delicious.

Yum, nice and light. I used a tad of coconut oil, maybe a teaspoon, to add sweetness. Omitted the maple syrup. At first I made one large pancake but when I tried a tablespoon of batter at a time they fluffed up nicely over medium low heat and bubbled up pretty quickly, sign of being ready to flip.

I am surprised by the number of positive reviews - I was VERY disappointed. The taste is acceptable but the texture of the batter is terrible. It was a nightmare to work with. The pancakes crumble and fall apart. It looked and tasted grainy - eating them was comparable to eating a soggy almond cookie.

With suggestions from other reviewers, I used almond milk instead of water and added some nutmeg, cinnamon, vanilla and baking soda. I also tried a trick I recently saw online...cut bananas into bite sized rounds, dip into the batter, then cook as normal. Came out really good! Only issue is the you have to cook the rounds on all sides so a little time consuming, but worth it in the end!
A simple, quick and flavourful pancake. I added a banana and some walnuts. Very very good. This is now my go-to recipe.
These are now my too go to pancakes now. I did substitute vegan brown rice syrup for maple. And as another person did, added a mashed banana. They were yum.
I made them exactly how they were listed except I halved the recipe. I made one pancake and added a little vanilla and it was fantastic. Being on a low-carb diet this was a great addition to my diet
It was a nice and easy recipe. I substituted water with almond milk instead. I will add a banana next time for more sweetness.
Snow day! I used flaxseed eggs, coconut oil, and put blueberries in. Hubby said it's a do over!
I love this recipe I make it at least 2 times a week.

I keep trying to like almond flour because I hav to watch carbs. This recipe wasn't much different than others. I used super fine almond flour but the pancakes turned out REALLY grainy. They fell apart easily & I didn't care for the taste. Tried peanut butter on them cuz I love pancakes with peanut butter, didn't help. Then tried sugarless peach preserves, nope. I don't care for maple syrup on my cakes, in recipes, ok, on, nope. Sorry but the only thing I liked about these were the carb count. The hunt continues.........

This recipe was very easy to make. I added about 1/2 teaspoon of baking powder to give my pancake a rise, which is did beautifully. Plus I added honey in place of the maple syrup. These pancakes not only look good but the tasted good.

As other reviewers suggested, I added some nutmeg, lemon juice and baking soda, I omitted the syrup, not sure if I cooked it too long or it’s because i made some additions/subtractions, but they tasted dry, I wouldn’t make it again.
not enough water and batter would not stick. i dont think this recipe is right.
These come out light and fluffy. Definitely a keeper.
It was great. I doubled it and put half in the freezer.
Loved this recipe!

I read the other reviews and made certain changes: I used whole milk instead of water, added two packs of stevia, used sugar-free syrup instead of maple...and accidentally put the cooking oil in the mix instead of cooking the batter in it. But...they came out delicious! Oh and I forgot to add the salt but I really can’t tell it’s missing, to be honest! Great recipe! Thanks Allie!
They turned out pretty good, but the texture was different.
I was really good
Dry and almost plastic-y. Would not make this recipe again. Needs more fat.

This is a really good basic recipe just like the description says. I added half of a banana, 2tsp vanilla, monk fruit instead of syrup(just to cut back on calories), and a tbsp of powdered almond butter. I do like to add blueberries if I have them.

I don’t usually leave food recipe reviews, however I wanted to for this one. Obviously gluten free pancakes aren’t ever going to be as fluffy as regular ones, but this recipe is pretty tasty and so easy. I made lots of almond flour pancake recipes from online and lots of them were fails, they would crumble and be just too soft and falling apart. These stay together, are easy to whip up, and taste pretty good as an alternative. Again, it’s not like regular pancakes bc it’s hard to repeat that type of consistency with almond flour, but for what it is, it’s good!

Great recipe! I followed all the suggested proportions and made a few modifications – used oat milk instead of water, added some cinnamon and vanilla, and added a pinch of baking powder for fluffiness. Topped it off with chocolate chips and blueberries for a delicious gluten and dairy free breakfast!
Not bad. will make again. Only used 1 egg due to a shortage, 2 might have helped them set better. Added vanilla, baking powder, and baking soda.
I really liked making them! i made 3 bigger ones though it makes really small ones if 4, topped w a few berries! Yummo

I added blueberries & I think they are needed (chopped banana would work as well) for moisture and I ended up with one extra pancake because of the volume the blueberries added to the batter. Just don't add frozen berries - they will make the batter too thick (almost freezes it).
Easy and tasty!

I used "flaxseed meal egg substitute" (1 tsp flaxseed meal + 3 tsp water = 1 egg) instead of eggs, and a little more than 1/4 cup water. Will substitute Monk Fruit sweetener next time for maple syrup so even fewer carbs. Pancakes were just delicious with rasberries &/or dipping into a little maple syrup!

Way too dry! 
I would use a banana or yogurt to make it moist. No water but coconut oil or almond milk and I always use real vanilla 1/4 tsp and 1/4 cinnamon. I put blueberries in my 1st try with this recipe but it was still too dry. Will try again using my own additions! Baking powder non aluminum will also help fluff them puppies up! So really this is a whole new recipe now!

Success! I loved it and kids too. Very easy to make. We actually cooked together (she is 2, he is 4) veeeeery easy to make. I will definitely do it again. Perhaps once a week. I used honey instead of maple syrup. That was the only change.
I followed the recipe exactly and they turned out a little dry. They were still a great quick pancake, next time I’ll make adjustments.
loved them!
liked

I really enjoyed these pancakes with almond flour. So much simpler than all the other recipes for them and they came out tasty and even kosher for Passover. I was worried because a friend told me the almond flour would be heavy, but we didn't have a problem until the last few, when we had to add a little more liquid. I will make them again for sure.
Made exactly like recipe and they're amazing! I sprinkled with cinnamon and stevia for a sweet treat
Yummy! It only makes 3-4 medium sized pancakes which is perfect for us!

Use milk instead of water. 
Smells like toasted almonds.
Added some whole wheat flour to give body. Like a table spoon. 
I don't do gluten free or keto.
Keto made my hubby's issues with copper intake horrible
This is a good recipe however the pancakes can turn out a little too dense.
Added blueberries, really good

Delicious! Great taste! I do substitute Maple syrup with Steen's 100% Pure Cane Syrup. I use pure cane syrup, 1. because I was raised on it here in Louisiana, 2. taste great, 3. better for you because, it's the real thing, and 4. a lot lower in carbs than other syrups. I already ate one, that's why there is only 3 on the plate. One is all I can eat. Very filling.
I've tried numerous almond flour pancake recipes and this one was the simplest and had the best taste.
Flat fall apart bitter pancakes
Will take some getting use to but I like them.
I added 1/4 tsp maple flavoring and 1/4 tsp vanilla flavoring and added 3 packets of Splenda
You could add some cinnamon to it to make them a bit more flavorful... but really good and hit the spot!
Easy and yummy

These were delicious! I love the nuttiness of the almond flour. I did make 2 adjustments that I think made them less dense than they were reported as being (mine were nice and light): Substituted 1% Milk for the water and added a teaspoon of Baking Powder, and I let the batter rest for about an hour before I made them. I also threw some cinnamon in...because I like cinnamon in my pancakes! Will definitely make these again!
Of course this is not a real pancake but it will do and probably a lot less fattening than the real McCoy. very easy and fast to make too
Delicious
Perfect, easy recipe! I added 1tsp of cinnamon and used almond milk for the water/liquid. I think I like them better than regular pancakes!
I substituted keto friendly maple syrup for regular maple syrup.

I didn’t make any changes to this recipe but I think I’ll add cinnamon next time. I like that the cakes are not too sweet. I also like that it only makes 4 cakes so that I don’t overindulge. These are a welcome change.

I made these pancakes just as they are and they were good. Next time though, I will add just a touch more Monk Fruit to the recipe and see if that will make them a little better. If not, I will try a different ingredient to enhance the flavor a little more. All in all though, they are good.
I added 1 tsp Vanilla, and 1 Tablespoon of Sour Cream. Turned out delicious.

I use one tablespoon of Lakanto monk fruit sweetener instead of syrup, and add a half teaspoon of baking powder to make them a little fluffier. I also like to add some vanilla, almond, or lemon extract for some fun flavor!
Used date syrup as the sweetener to be whole30 compliant .
These were very good! I added vanilla, cinnamon and nutmeg. We will definitely have these again!

Sadly, this didn’t work at all for me. And I doubled the recipe in hopes of freezing some for breakfast during the week. I couldn’t get the batter to bind, even with an extra egg. I tried it both waffle and pancake style. Waffles just wedged in my maker. Pancakes heated beautifully, but crumbled and smoothed on flip. *sad face*

It’s real easy to make, the consistency is perfect for cooking. Not too runny and not super thick. The flavor is kind of plain for my kids, with some pure maple syrup it taste fine though, they still gobble them all up.
Really enjoyed these, I would double the batch since it didn't make as much as we wanted.

It was a decent recipe. Very easy to make. It was also my 1st experience using almond flour. I can't blame the recipe for not liking it a whole lot. Almond flour just has a less satisfying texture for me. That being said, my kids both liked them so as a healthier option I may make them again and grow to like them more. I did use milk instead of water and after I tried a couple I ended up adding a quarter cup greek yogurt and a few pinches of baking powder. It helped a little but I still felt I was chewing on ground nuts. lol (I hope someone else gets a good laugh with me.)
My husband and I really love these pancakes. I didn’t make any changes. Yes I will make them often. I served my pancakes with sugar-free maple syrup.

They fell apart when I flipped them. But the only eggs we had were frozen from the back of our fridge, so I had to use the whites after thawing them and I probably flipped too soon. Oh well. Better luck next time.
I followed the recipe and found these very flavorful in a pleasant way!
I added blueberries which helped with the flavor and dryness, a little

Just made this this morning For my kids and they definitely were not happy the did not want to eat them after trying them for myself they were a bit dry and didn't have much Flavor. If I make these again I will definitely add a sugar substitute and maybe a banana or something.
These are so easy and good. I sometimes use them as a soft cookie like treat.
Easy recipe, tasty.
Brunt outside, raw inside, unflippable

I made these, just a few minutes ago, actually-- And taste wise, they are amazing, instead of maple syrup, I used 1 and a 1/2 tsp of Pyure sugar substitute, 2/8th cinnamon (Smell was there, but taste didn't follow through, so needed a bit more!), 1 tsp of vanilla, 1/2 tsp of baking soda (After reading comments for less denser pancakes), and only used 1 egg, and 1/4th cup of unsweetened almond milk, with a splash extra to give it a nice smooth consistency--- The batter looked so nice, and smelled heavenly, but like many of the other commenters, it did end up being on the dry side, and a few fell apart on the edges , I suppose that has more to do with the almond flour, than anything else, though. Would definitely make these again, but double the recipe, because it only made 12 slight bigger than silver dollar sized, so it fed 3 people, 4 lil pancakes each. Small dollop of whipped cream and fresh fruit, you can easily dress this up and make it beautiful and elegant. Great base recipe
I was pleasantly surprised! These are good! I omitted the salt and added 2 tblsp of syrup vs 1. Very good!
VERY dry
How much is one serving of these pancakes?
i made this KETO sugar free and delicious. I altered by adding salted carmel extract, replaced water with rich coconut milk and used Walden Farm syrup to eliminate carbs and sugar. Great tase!
Love these! Made them this morning for the first time. Added chocolate chips. Yum!
I added cream for half the quantity of water.
We really liked these! We added a little agave along with the maple syrup, and a pinch of vanilla.
These were good. Reminds me more of Jonny Cakes than pancakes.

Used whole milk instead of water, added another slosh of maple syrup, 1/8 cup more almond flour, 1 tsp baking powder and 1/2 cup fresh blueberries. I wanted a thicker, fluffier pancake that held blueberries well and they turned out wonderfully!
Added blueberries. Pancakes didn't hold together very well. Need more elasticity. Tasted good.
I just made this recipe and was very disappointed . Batter was runny and they were not fluffy.

Doing whole 30 so adjusted the recipe a bit. Used a mashed banana instead of syrup and added a little cinnamon. Cooked in coconut oil. Pretty tasty, not sweet, but good with some berries for a different breakfast.
Love these better than traditional pancakes! Vanilla extract increases the flavor.
